security: Disclosing O'Connell's specific roles within the Office of Security, his work on Agency-wide policies, and his involvement with U.S. government agencies could reveal sensitive security protocols. Describing his supervisory roles in investigative and operational intelligence support could expose specific intelligence methods, harming security operations. Directly quoting: "Executive direction, supervision and acted as principal advisor... security support for all Agency activities and operations... formulated and recommended security policies and procedures...investigative and operational intelligence support..."
summary: The documents relate to James P. O'Connell, Jr.'s retirement from the CIA and his recognition with the Intelligence Medal of Merit for his service from December 1951 to June 1973.
summary_one_paragraph: These documents detail the voluntary retirement of James P. O'Connell, Jr., a Security Officer (GS-16) in the CIA's Office of Security, effective June 29, 1973, after 21 years of service. Included is a memorandum recommending his retirement approval, a report from the Honor and Merit Awards Board recommending O'Connell receive the Intelligence Medal of Merit for his meritorious service between September 1965 and June 1973, and a letter from Director W.E. Colby congratulating O'Connell on his retirement and acknowledging his contributions. O'Connell's employment summary indicates his roles included executive direction, supervision, and advising on physical, technical, and overseas security matters.
title: O'CONNELL, JAMES
recipient: Director of Security and Deputy Director for Management and Services
